[[Billy Horschel]] (2009) }} [[Image:University of Florida Golf Course.jpg|right|thumb|290px|The [[Mark Bostick Golf Course]], home course of the Florida Gators men's and women's golf teams.]] The '''Florida Gators men's golf''' team represents the [[University of Florida]] in the sport of [[golf]]. The Gators compete in [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) and the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC). They play their home matches on the [[Mark Bostick Golf Course]] on the university's [[Gainesville, Florida]] campus, and are currently led by head coach [[Buddy Alexander]]. In the eighty-six year history of the Gators' men's golf program, they have won fifteen SEC championships and four NCAA national tournament championships. == History == The Gators men's golf program was the fifth intercollegiate sports team established by the University of Florida, having begun competition in 1925.Julian M. Pleasants, ''Gator Tales: An Oral History of the University of Florida'', University of Florida, Gainesville, Florida, pp. 55, 245–246. (2006). The Gators won their first two Southeastern Conference team championships twenty years later under coach Andrew Bracken in 1955 and coach [[Conrad Rehling]] in 1956. Those two SEC championship teams produced future PGA Tour members [[Doug Sanders]], [[Tommy Aaron]] and [[Dave Ragan]]. Rehling's Gators also produced three back-to-back individual SEC titles: Ragan (1956) and Aaron (1957, 1958). === Bishop era: 1964–1978 === Physical education professor and former high school football coach [[Buster Bishop]] became the new head coach of the Gators golf team in 1964. Improvement came quickly for Bishop's Gators, and they finished as the SEC runners-up in 1965. Gator [[Bob Murphy (golfer)|Bob Murphy]] won the individual NCAA national title in 1966. And in 1967, the team finished second in the conference behind the [[LSU Tigers]], and second in the nation behind the [[Houston Cougars]] at the [[NCAA Division I Men's Golf Championships|NCAA championship tournament]]. The 1968 Gators made history; they not only won the program's third SEC team championship, they won the NCAA championship tournament by edging the defending national champion [[Houston Cougars]] by two shots.Pat Putnam, "[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1081336/index.htm Two Splashes Bring An End To A Long Reign]," ''Sports Illustrated'' (July 1, 1968). Retrieved July 18, 2011.Robbie Andreu, "[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090604/ARTICLES/906049981/1136/sports Top 25 Gator teams: #20 1968 Men's golf]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (June 5, 2009). Retrieved August 8, 2009. The Gators' 1968 NCAA men's golf championship, won by John Darr, [[Steve Melnyk]], John Sale, Richard Spears and Wendell Coffee, was the first national team championship in any sport ever won by a team from the University of Florida. Bishop's Gators won another NCAA national team championship 1973,Robbie Andreu, "[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090618/ARTICLES/906049959/1136/sports Top 25 Gator teams: #8 1973 Men's golf]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (June 18, 2009). Retrieved August 8, 2009. with an all-star team of four future PGA Tour members: [[Gary Koch]], [[Andy Bean]], Ben Duncan, [[Woody Blackburn]] and [[Phil Hancock]]. The 1973 Gators outpaced the second-place [[Oklahoma State Cowboys]] by ten strokes in the NCAA championship tournament. The following year, the Gators finished second by two strokes behind the [[Wake Forest Demon Deacons]] at the 1974 NCAA championship tournament. Bishop's teams also won three back-to-back SEC team championships in 1973, 1974 and 1975. Only once in fifteen seasons did his Gators finish worse than third in the ten-team SEC. Bishop retired from coaching after the 1978 season. === Darr and Blevins: 1979–1987 === John Darr, a junior letterman from the Gators' 1968 national championship team, followed Bishop as the team's coach in 1979 and 1980. In his two seasons, Darr's Gators finished second and third in the SEC, and fifteenth and tenth nationally at the NCAA championship tournament. Gator golfer [[Rick Pearson (golfer)|Rick Pearson]] won the individual SEC title in 1980. Lynn Blevins served as the Gators' coach from 1981 to 1987; his teams won an SEC team championship in 1985, and were the SEC runners-up in 1986. Blevins' Gators finished third in the nation at the 1985 NCAA championship tournament, which they hosted on their home course. === Alexander era: 1988 to present === The Gators' current head coach, Buddy Alexander, was hired for the 1988 season. Alexander's 1993 team of Guy Hill, [[Chris Couch (golfer)|Chris Couch]], [[Brian Gay]], Bread Lehman and John Pettit won another national championship, besting second-place [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets]] by a single shot at the NCAA championship tournament.Robbie Andreu, "[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090602/ARTICLES/906029916/1136/sports Top 25 Gator teams: #23 1993 Men's Golf]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (June 2, 2009). Retrieved August 8, 2009. His 2001 team won the program's fourth NCAA national championship, with Gators [[Nick Gilliam]], Camilo Benedetti, [[Bubba Dickerson]], [[Camilo Villegas]] and Ben Banks dominating the runner-up [[Clemson Tigers]] by eighteen strokes.Kevin Brockway, "[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090613/ARTICLES/906139897 Top 25 Gator teams: #12 2001 Men's golf]," ''The Gainesville Sun'' (June 13, 2009). Retrieved August 8, 2009. Team captain Gilliam also won the second individual NCAA men's golf championship in Gators history in 2001,NCAA, NCAA History, Division I Men's Golf History, [http://www.ncaa.com/history/m-golf-d1.html Division I Champions]. Retrieved August 8, 2009. and teammate Benedetti finished second in the NCAA championship tournament, three strokes behind Gilliam. To date, Alexander's Gators have won eight SEC team championships (1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1999, 2003, 2011), and finished second in the conference seven times. Nationally, his teams have won two NCAA national championships (1993, 2001), and finished second twice (1990, 2006). The Gators have failed to qualify for the NCAA championship tournament only once in his twenty-three seasons. == Individual honors == In the past fifty-six years, fifteen Gators golfers have won twenty-one SEC individual titles.SECSports.com, SEC Record Book, [http://cache.secsports.com/doc_lib/mgol_records.pdf Men's Golf]. Retrieved August 8, 2009 Thirty-nine Gators golfers have earned sixty-seven first-team All-SEC honors. Forty-nine Gators have received ninety-three [[All-American]] honors.''Florida Gators Men's Golf 2008 Media Guide'', [http://www.gatorzone.com/golf/men/media/2008/pdf/5_history.pdf Team History]. Retrieved August 7, 2009. Two Gators have won the individual NCAA national title: Bob Murphy (1966), and Nick Gilliam (2001). Four Gators have won [[United States Amateur Championship (golf)|U.S. Amateur Championship]]: Bob Murphy (1965), Steve Melnyk (1969), [[Fred Ridley]] (1975), and Bubba Dickerson (2001). The Gators' current coach, Buddy Alexander, won the U.S. Amateur in 1986. Melnyk won the [[British Amateur]] in 1971. == PGA Tour professionals == {{main|List of Florida Gators golfers}} Over thirty former University of Florida alumni have represented the university on the [[PGA Tour]], including former Gators golfers [[Tommy Aaron]], winner of the 1973 [[Masters Tournament]] and two other Tour events, [[Mark Calcavecchia]], winner of the 1989 [[The Open|British Open]] and thirteen other Tour events, [[Andy North]], winner of the 1978 and 1985 [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]s and one other Tour event, and [[Doug Sanders]], winner of twenty Tour events. == Coaching staff == Buddy Alexander is the head coach of the Florida Gators men's golf team; 2011–2012 will be his twenty-fifth season with the Gators.GatorZone.com, Golf, Coaching & Support Staff, [http://www.gatorzone.com/golf/men/coaches.php?staff=alexander Buddy Alexander]. Retrieved July 25, 2011. The Golf Coaches Association of America (GCAA) has honored him as its National Coach of the Year three times, and the GCAA inducted him into its Coaches Hall of Fame in 2001, joining former Gators coach Bishop Buster, who was inducted in 1982.Golf Coaches Association of America, [http://collegiategolf.com/awards/hall-of-fame.html GCAA Coaches Hall of Fame]. Retrieved July 25, 2011. Alexander's fellow SEC coaches have recognized him seven times as the SEC Coach of the Year. He previously coached the men's and women's golf teams at [[Louisiana State University]] (LSU) from 1983 to 1987, and the men's golf team at [[Georgia Southern University]] from 1977 to 1980. == Mark Bostick Golf Course == The Gators men's golf team host its home matches at the [[Mark Bostick Golf Course]], located on {{convert|110|acre|km2}} of the university's campus in Gainesville, Florida.GatorZone.com, Golf, Facilities, [http://www.gatorzone.com/golf/men/media/2006/pdf/uf/facilities.pdf Florida Golf Facilities]. Retrieved August 8, 2009. The university course was originally designed by noted Scottish golfer and golf course architect [[Donald Ross (golfer)|Donald Ross]] in 1921.Donald Ross Society, [http://www.donaldross.org/Content/Members/MemberPublicProfile.aspx?pageId=130616&memberId=385747 University of Florida Golf Club]. Retrieved August 8, 2009. It was partially redesigned and rebuilt by noted golf architect [[Bobby Weed]] as part of a $4 million renovation project in 2001.John Garrity, "[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1021763/index.htm Look Out Below! There's more to the upcoming renovation at Florida than meets the eye]," ''Sports Illustrated'' (February 12, 2001). Retrieved August 8, 2009. The renovated course is a 6,701-yard par 70, and the facilities include the Guy Bostick club house and dedicated practice areas for the Gators golf teams.John Garrity, "[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1023818/index.htm Taking A Stand: Stretched to the max, the Florida layout highlights the divide within the golf industry]," ''Sports Illustrated'' (October 1, 2001). Retrieved August 8, 2009. The Mark Bostick Golf Course hosts the annual Gator Invitational,"[http://www.gatorzone.com/story.php?id=15318 UF hosts 32nd Annual SunTrust Gator Invitational this weekend]," GatorZone.com (February 13, 2009). Retrieved August 8, 2009. as well as the annual Gator Golf Day alumni event.University of Florida Golf Course, [http://www.ufgolfcourse.com/tournament/ 40th Annual Gator Golf Day]. Retrieved August 8, 2009. == See also == {{Portal box|Florida|Golf}} *[[Florida Gators]] *[[Florida Gators women's golf]] *[[History of the University of Florida]] *[[List of Florida Gators golfers]] *[[List of University of Florida Athletic Hall of Fame members#Men's golf|List of University of Florida Athletic Hall of Fame members]] *[[University of Florida Athletic Association|University Athletic Association]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == *[http://www.gatorsports.com GatorSports.com] – Florida Gators sports news from ''The Gainesville Sun''. *[http://www.gatorzone.com/golf/men/ GatorZone.com] – Official webpage of the Florida Gators men's golf team. {{Florida Gators athletic program navbox}} [[Category:College golf teams in the United States]] [[Category:Florida Gators men's golf|*]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in 1925]]
